content.heading: Learning Objectives
content.text: Verbs are the engines of sentences - they drive action and show time. Mastering verb agreement and tense will make your writing powerful and clear.
bullet_points: Conquer subject-verb agreement in complex sentences

content.heading: The Fundamental Rule
content.text: Subjects and verbs must agree in number: singular subjects take singular verbs, plural subjects take plural verbs.

concept_box.title: Agreement Rules
points: üéØ **Find the real subject** - ignore distractors between subject and verb
‚ö†Ô∏è **Watch prepositional phrases** - they don't change the subject

examples.correct: The box of papers is heavy. (box = singular subject)
examples.incorrect: The box of papers are heavy. (papers is NOT the subject)

elements.reveal: Cross out prepositional phrases: 'The box [of papers] is heavy.' Now the agreement is obvious!

strategy_steps.title: FIND the verb
strategy_steps.description: Locate the action or state of being word
strategy_steps.example: The team of players (practices/practice) daily ‚Üí Verb: practices or practice?

strategy_steps.title: IDENTIFY the subject
strategy_steps.description: Ask 'who or what' performs the action
strategy_steps.example: What practices? The team ‚Üí Subject: team (singular)

strategy_steps.title: NARROW down distractors
strategy_steps.description: Cross out prepositional phrases and interrupting words
strategy_steps.example: The team [of players] practices ‚Üí Clear subject-verb pair

strategy_steps.title: DECIDE on agreement
strategy_steps.description: Match singular subject with singular verb

content.heading: SAT Favorites: Common Tricks
content.text: The SAT loves to test agreement in these challenging scenarios. Master them and you'll ace every verb question!

concept_box.title: Watch Out For These
points: üë• **Collective nouns** - Usually singular (The team wins, The family agrees)
üìã **Either/or, Neither/nor** - Agrees with the closest subject
üîÑ **There is/are** - Real subject comes after the verb
‚ûï **Along with, as well as** - Don't make subjects plural

examples.collective: The committee has decided. (committee = one unit)
examples.either_or: Either the cats or the dog needs food. (closest subject: dog = singular)

elements.reveal: Collective nouns = one group acting together. Either/or = the closer one wins. There is/are = flip the sentence to check.

passage.text: The collection of rare books (belong/belongs) to the university library. Neither the students nor the professor (understand/understands) the complex cataloging system. There (is/are) several ancient manuscripts that require special handling. The team of librarians, along with their supervisor, (work/works) tirelessly to preserve these treasures.

guided_questions.question: What's the subject in the first sentence?
guided_questions.hint: Cross out the prepositional phrase 'of rare books'
guided_questions.explanation: The collection [of rare books] belongs ‚Üí collection is singular, so use 'belongs'

guided_questions.question: Which subject controls the verb in 'Neither...nor'?
guided_questions.hint: Look at the subject closest to the verb
guided_questions.explanation: Neither/nor construction: verb agrees with the closest subject (professor = singular)

guided_questions.question: What's the real subject in 'There (is/are)...'?
guided_questions.hint: Flip the sentence: 'Several ancient manuscripts _____ there'
guided_questions.explanation: There are several manuscripts ‚Üí manuscripts is plural, so use 'are'

guided_questions.question: Does 'along with' change the subject?
guided_questions.hint: 'Along with' is like a prepositional phrase
guided_questions.explanation: The team [along with their supervisor] works ‚Üí team stays singular

content.heading: Keeping Time Straight
content.text: Consistent verb tense helps readers follow your timeline. Unnecessary shifts confuse and distract from your message.

concept_box.title: Tense Consistency Rules
points: ‚è∞ **Stay in one time frame** unless logic requires a shift
üìñ **Match the context** - past events use past tense throughout
‚úÖ **Check for logic** - does the timeline make sense?

examples.consistent: Maria studied hard and passed her exam with flying colors.
examples.inconsistent: Maria studied hard and passes her exam with flying colors.

elements.reveal: Create a mental timeline: if one verb is past, related actions should usually be past too, unless there's a clear reason to shift.

passage.text: The group of scientists were excited about their discovery. Each of the researchers have contributed valuable insights, and there was many breakthrough moments during the project. Neither the initial hypothesis nor the final results was what the team had originally expected.

question.text: Which choice corrects all the verb agreement errors?
options: The group of scientists was excited about their discovery. Each of the researchers has contributed valuable insights, and there were many breakthrough moments during the project. Neither the initial hypothesis nor the final results were what the team had originally expected.

The group of scientists were excited about their discovery. Each of the researchers have contributed valuable insights, and there were many breakthrough moments during the project. Neither the initial hypothesis nor the final results were what the team had originally expected.

The group of scientists was excited about their discovery. Each of the researchers have contributed valuable insights, and there was many breakthrough moments during the project. Neither the initial hypothesis nor the final results was what the team had originally expected.

The group of scientists were excited about their discovery. Each of the researchers has contributed valuable insights, and there were many breakthrough moments during the project. Neither the initial hypothesis nor the final results was what the team had originally expected.

explanations.A: ‚úì Correct! Group (singular) was; Each (singular) has; there were moments (plural); Neither...nor results (closest subject 'results' is plural) were.
explanations.B: Group should be 'was' (singular), Each should be 'has' (singular).
explanations.C: Each should be 'has' (singular), there should be 'were' (moments is plural), Neither...nor should be 'were' (results is plural).
explanations.D: Group should be 'was' (singular), there should be 'were' (moments is plural), Neither...nor should be 'were' (results is plural).

key_points.title: Find the Real Subject
key_points.description: Cross out distractors like prepositional phrases to identify the true subject.

key_points.title: Match Singular to Singular
key_points.description: Singular subjects need singular verbs; plural subjects need plural verbs.

key_points.title: Keep Time Consistent
key_points.description: Stay in one tense unless logic requires a shift in timeline.

key_points.title: SAT Strategy
key_points.description: Use the FIND method and watch for collective nouns, either/or, and there is/are constructions.

passage.text: The team of researchers, along with their graduate assistant, were studying climate patterns when they discovered an unexpected trend. Each of their findings have contributed to a growing understanding of global weather systems. There was several factors that influenced their conclusions, and neither the original data nor the recent measurements was sufficient alone. The implications of their work extends far beyond their initial expectations.

practice_questions.question: Which sentence has correct subject-verb agreement?
options: The box of supplies are in the closet.
The box of supplies is in the closet.
Either the pens or the pencil are missing.
There is many students in the library.

strategy_card.title: Verb Agreement Quick Reference
steps: 1. FIND the verb in the sentence
2. IDENTIFY who or what does the action
3. NARROW down by crossing out distractors
tips: Collective nouns usually take singular verbs
Either/or and neither/nor agree with closest subject
There is/are - real subject comes after verb
Phrases like 'along with' don't change subject number

common_mistakes: Being distracted by words between subject and verb
Missing agreement in there is/are sentences
